title: Dildar (poet)
text:
Dildar, born Yûnis Reuf (, 20 February 1918 – October 20, 1948) was a <a href="Kurdish%20people">Kurdish</a> poet and political activist, best known for writing the Kurdish national anthem <a href="Ey%20Req%C3%AEb">Ey Reqîb</a>.
Early life and his studies.
Dildar was born on 20 February 1918 in the town of <a href="Koy%20Sanjaq">Koy Sanjaq</a> located in the <a href="Mosul%20Vilayet">Mosul Vilayet</a> of the <a href="Ottoman%20Empire">Ottoman Empire</a>. In his youth, he attended school in <a href="Ranya">Ranya</a>, high school in <a href="Kirkuk">Kirkuk</a> and moved to <a href="Baghdad">Baghdad</a> to study <a href="law">law</a>.
Life.
Literary style.
Many of his poems were written in the classical Kurdish style with <a href="quantitative%20rhythm">quantitative rhythm</a> and <a href="monorhyme">monorhyme</a>. His poems were published in the "Ronākī" and "Galawēz" literary journals in <a href="Erbil">Erbil</a> and <a href="Baghdad">Baghdad</a>. He moreover introduced romantic and realistic elements in Kurdish poetry.
Law.
He graduated as a lawyer in 1945 and practiced law to defend the poor, farmers, and defending the Kurdish issues in general.
Political activism.
He joined the newly formed Hewa Party in 1938, which became "[t]he first Kurdish organisation legally recognized, that seeks a united and free Kurdistan". Dildar relocated to <a href="Iranian%20Kurdistan">Iranian Kurdistan</a> to join the revolution led by <a href="Qazi%20Muhammad">Qazi Muhammad</a> against the government of Iran, which led to his infamous arrest in Iran.
Prison and death.
Ey Reqîb.
After being arrested, he was sent to prison in Iran, where he wrote the poem "<a href="Ey%20Req%C3%AEb">Ey reqîb</a>" meaning "Oh Enemy", in 1938, referencing the prison guards, and expressing that the Kurds were alive and will not back down from fighting for free a <a href="Kurdistan">Kurdistan</a>. His expression of frustration and direct confrontation with the occupiers of Kurdistan made "Ey reqib" a symbol in the Kurds cause for freedom.
Death and legacy.
Dildar died young at the age of 3‌0 and was buried in Erbil.
He lived to see his poem "Ey Reqîb" being adopted as the Kurdish national <a href="anthem">anthem</a>. Ey Reqîb was first played and sung in 1946 on the proclamation of the short-lived <a href="Republic%20of%20Mahabad">Republic of Mahabad</a>. Today the song is played as the official anthem of <a href="Kurdistan%20Region">Kurdistan Region</a> and widely adopted by Kurds in the four parts of <a href="Kurdistan">Kurdistan.</a>
